statements.name: PROC TEXTRULE
statements.description: The TEXTRULE procedure generates language interpretation for textual information (LITI) concept or fact rules by using annotated data.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: names the input data table for PROC TEXTRULE to use. The input data table contains annotated sentences. Each row corresponds to one sentence and must contain five variables.

arguments.name: CUTOFF=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of rules that are returned. By default, CUTOFF=500, which means that PROC TEXTRULE returns the first 500 rules according to their frequency.

arguments.name: EXCLUDE=
arguments.description: specifies the input table that contains the rules that you want to exclude. libref.data-table is a two-level name, where libref refers to the library, and data-table specifies the name of the input data table.

arguments.name: GENERATEFACT
arguments.description: determines whether to generate the fact rules. When you specify this option, PROC TEXTRULE generates fact rules only. By default, the procedure generates concept rules only.

arguments.name: LANGUAGE=
arguments.description: specifies the language that is used in the text variable of the input table. This value is either the name or the two-letter ISO 639-1 language code of a licensed language. If you omit this option, then the default language (English) is used.

arguments.name: NOPREDEFINEDNER
arguments.description: determines whether the predefined concepts model should be used to generate concept rules. If you omit this option, the predefined concepts model is used to generate concept rules.

arguments.name: REDUCE=
arguments.description: removes the rules from the output table if their frequency is less than n. The value of n must be a positive integer. By default, REDUCE=1, which means that no rule is removed.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement specifies the variable that contains the IDs of each sentence. This variable can be either a number or a string of characters. It is used to group data for generating fact rules.

statements.name: INPUT
statements.description: The INPUT statement specifies the options for input variables that contain the annotated data.

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: specifies the variable that contains the end position of the tagged term in the sentence. By default, END=_end_.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies the variable that contains the label of tagged terms. The labels are used as concept names in generated rules. By default, LABEL=_concept_.

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: specifies the variable that contains the start position of the tagged term in the sentence. By default, START=_start_.

arguments.name: TEXT=
arguments.description: specifies the variable that contains the text to be processed. This text contains tagged terms. By default, TEXT=_sentence_.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement creates an output data table that contains the generated rules.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the output data table.
